facts.text: Jaibai, widow of Buddhu, began to live with Faddi a few years after the death of her husband. Faddi and Jaibai at first lived at Agra, but later shifted to Morena. Jaibai had a son named Gulab, aged 11 years, by Buddhu.
Gulab lived in village Torkheda at the house of his phupa Ramle from Sawan 1961.
Gulab's corpse was recovered from a well of village Jarah on January 21, 1963, reaching Morena mortuary at 5:15 p.m. Despatched from place of occurrence at 1 p.m.
Dr. Nigam found injury on skull; boy died on account of that injury within two or three days of postmortem. No water found in lungs, abdomen, larynx or middle ear, ruling out drowning.

Police knew nothing of offence till 9 p.m. on January 20, 1963, when appellant Faddi lodged FIR at police station Saroichhola, stating he found his son lying dead in well near peepul tree of Hadpai on morning of January 20, 1963, after peeping into well. Narrated events accusing Ramle, Bhanta and one cyclist of murdering Gulab.
FIR led police to well and recovery of corpse.
Police arrested Ramle, Bhanta and Shyama (cyclist) by January 26; they remained in lock-up 8-11 days.
On January 26, investigation taken over by Circle Inspector Nazat Mohd. Khan from Rajender Singh.
Circle Inspector arrested Faddi on January 27; other arrested persons released.
Faddi took Circle Inspector to house and delivered pair of shorts of Gulab.

Faddi went to house of Ramle at about noon on January 19, 1963, asked Ramle to send boy with him. Gulab was in fields. After meals, Faddi left suddenly when Shyama arrived with message from Gulab's mother not to send boy with anyone. Faddi caught hold of Gulab from fields forcibly and took him away (Banwari also said to be with Faddi).
Gulab not seen alive after Faddi took him on afternoon of January 19, 1963.
Corpse recovered on forenoon of January 21, 1963.
Faddi gave no satisfactory explanation as to how he and Gulab parted company.
Faddi knew place where Gulab's corpse lay; his information led to recovery.

Faddi's statement that he saw corpse floating on morning of January 20 untrue, as per Dr. Nigam corpse could float after approx. two days. Witnesses said could not see floating, recovered using angles.
Faddi's confession to Jaibai, Jimipal and Sampatti about killing Gulab (High Court did not rely).
Pair of shorts recovered was one Gulab wearing when taken by Faddi (evidence discrepant; High Court did not rely).

Appellant denies going to Ramle's house and taking Gulab forcibly on January 19; admits lodging report and recovery with angle. States lodged report on tutoring of Lalla Ram of Utampur, no evidence. In report, admits taking Gulab forcibly, then accuses Ramle, Bhatta, Shyamlal of threatening, taking pyjama and half-pant, taking boy to well, throwing something in well; appellant hid, heard sound, saw them run, peeped next morning, consulted vakil and lodged report.
Additional Sessions Judge, Morena convicted and sentenced Faddi to death under s.302 IPC.
Madhya Pradesh High Court, Gwalior Bench confirmed conviction and sentence on July 27, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 83 of 1963 and Criminal Reference No. 4 of 1963.

legal_issues.text: Whether the circumstances established are sufficient to prove that appellant committed murder of Gulab.
Whether the first information report lodged by appellant is admissible in evidence.

petitioner_arguments.text: Evidence is unreliable and should not have been accepted by courts below.
First information report inadmissible in evidence, relying on Nisar Ali v. State of U.P.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Nisar Ali v. State of U.P.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant denies taking Gulab forcibly; FIR admits prosecution up to taking away but accuses others; tutored by Lalla Ram.

respondent_arguments.text: Circumstances prove appellant murdered Gulab: last seen with him, knew body location, untrue explanations.

court_reasoning.text: Courts below correctly appreciated evidence; no need to discuss again. Evidence of Ramle PW15, Bhanta alias Dhanta PW4, Shyamlal PW5 accepted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant denies key facts but courts accepted prosecution witnesses.

court_reasoning.text: FIR not confession but admission of facts under s.21 Evidence Act; admissible against maker. Not barred by s.25 Evidence Act or s.162 CrPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes Nisar Ali as referring to confessional FIRs.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's FIR statements false; burden on him to explain disappearance after taking boy. No action after alleged threats by others.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If others took boy forcibly, appellant would have acted, not hidden all night.

court_reasoning.text: Circumstances sufficient: appellant last with deceased, knew body location, untrue explanations in FIR and court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court rightly did not rely on confession or shorts recovery due to discrepancies.

holdings.text: Circumstances held established sufficient to conclude Gulab murdered by appellant.
First information report admissible as admission under s.21 Evidence Act, not confession.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nisar Ali v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Observation on FIR admissibility refers to confessional FIRs, not applicable here.
FIR not confession but information/charge; admissible as against maker, variances discredit defence.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Shiv Singh

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction and death sentence under s.302 IPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: FIR as admission under s.21; s.17 defines admission; not barred by s.25.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: FIR not statement to police during investigation, not barred by s.162.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; conviction and death sentence under s.302 IPC confirmed.

key_quotes.text: "The circumstances held established by the High Court are sufficient, in our opinion, to reach the conclusion that Gulab was murdered by the appellant who was the last person in whose company the deceased was seen alive and who knew where the dead body lay and who gave untrue explanation about his knowing it in the report lodged by him and gave no explanation in Court as to how he separated from the deceased."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on circumstantial evidence sufficiency.

key_quotes.text: "The report is not a confession of the appellant. It is not a statement made to a police officer during the course of investigation. Section 25 of the Evidence Act and s. 162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure do not bar its admissibility."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rules on FIR admissibility as admission.
